conclusion: Analyze the motion of the slider and the ball using conservation of energy and momentum.
Slider starts from rest at height h and slides down inclined track AB with angle θ = 37°.
Length of inclined track is L = h/sin 37° = h/0.6.
Work done by friction is W_friction = -μmg cos 37° * L = -μmg cos 37° * h/sin 37°.
Total work done is W_total = mgh - W_friction.
Kinetic energy at bottom of incline is 1/2 mv_P^2 = mgh - μmg cos 37° * h/sin 37°.
Speed of slider at point P is v_P = √(2g(h - μh cot 37°)).
Collision is elastic and masses are equal.
Speed of slider after collision is v_slider = v_P.
Ball must barely pass highest point E.
Speed at highest point E is v_E = √(gR).
Using conservation of mechanical energy, 1/2 mv_F^2 = 1/2 mv_E^2 + mg(2R).
Speed of ball at point F is v_F = √(v_E^2 + 4gR) = √(5gR).
Ball leaves track DEF with vertical component v_Fy = v_F sin θ and horizontal component v_Fx = v_F cos θ.
Time of flight determined by vertical motion: H = v_Fy t - 1/2 gt^2.
Horizontal distance x is x = v_Fx t.
Substituting values, x = √(5gR) cos θ * (√(5gR) sin θ ± √((5gR sin θ)^2 + 2gH))/g.
Maximum distance occurs with positive root: x_max = √(5gR) cos θ * √((5gR sin θ)^2 + 2gH)/g.
